content: quote: Military weaponry and supplies, everything from fighter jet parts to meals for combat soldiers, are vanishing from the U.S. government inventory. A recent government report says some of that lost equipment could be used against America’s military and police agencies. A weapon stash in Juarez and night-vision rifle scopes stolen from combat teams in Iraq for sale on the black market in El Paso are part of a wider problem, according to the 2008 Government Accountability Office report. (El Paso Times, March 18, 2009, Pg. 1) How is this happening??
quote: Military weaponry and supplies, everything from fighter jet parts to meals for combat soldiers, are vanishing from the U.S. government inventory. A recent government report says some of that lost equipment could be used against America’s military and police agencies. A weapon stash in Juarez and night-vision rifle scopes stolen from combat teams in Iraq for sale on the black market in El Paso are part of a wider problem, according to the 2008 Government Accountability Office report. (El Paso Times, March 18, 2009, Pg. 1)
title: Military Weaponry from U.S. Government Inventory for Sale in El Paso’s Black Market

title: Military Weaponry from U.S. Government Inventory for Sale in El Paso’s Black Market

content: I can get MRE's on the open market, and while they suck they certainly arent a weapon. Fighter Jet parts could be anything from a fastener to coded out fan blades. Night Vision is disturbing, though IIRC the Miscreant who allegedly stole them was caught along with the chain of custody that sold them. Where's the Military Issue Weapons? Any M-4's, M16A2/A4's? Also is any provided through FARC from Venezuelan or Captured Colombian Sources? in the late 1970's Street Gangs in LA had a few M16A1's that were issued to the ARVN. FARC recently was found to be using CAVIM ammo.

Well for one thing genius not one actual weapon is mentioned in his blurb. In reading the entire article it Mentioned 1 M16 & 1 M60 Light Machinegun(functionability unknown) as attempted to be sold to Colombian Rebels,not to Mexico and seized by ICE. The Pictures shows seized Civilian Arms, not US Military Issue. The Grenades used in Picture are Dummy Grenades used in throwing practice that anyone who ever Served in a Ground Component of their Military would recognize as such. I could as easily make a Grenade from a Soup can. F-14 Fighter parts arent going to miraculously fly themselves into a functioning Aircraft capable of Sorties. Night Vision Devices being used are indeed a Bad trend but I can Legally buy such devices now, both in this country and around the globe. Reading Comprehension goes a Long way Canadian, try it sometime.

content: quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: In reading the entire article it Mentioned 1 M16 & 1 M60 Light Machinegun(functionability unknown) as attempted to be sold to Colombian Rebels,not to Mexico and seized by ICE. The Pictures shows seized Civilian Arms, not US Military Issue. What about the Barrett sniper rifles the cartels have acquired? The Grenades used in Picture are Dummy Grenades used in throwing practice that anyone who ever Served in a Ground Component of their Military would recognize as such. I could as easily make a Grenade from a Soup can. Why would the cartels go through so much trouble to acquire practice grenades if they could make them out of soup cans, as you say? There have been 10 documented grenade attacks in Mexico this year. BTW, the M69 practice grenades I threw in my time were light blue. The real ones (M67) were OD green. F-14 Fighter parts arent going to miraculously fly themselves into a functioning Aircraft capable of Sorties. The Iranians were trying to acquire the parts to keep their F-14s flying. They went to a lot of trouble to get them, so they must have really needed them. Night Vision Devices being used are indeed a Bad trend but I can Legally buy such devices now, both in this country and around the globe. I'm sure that makes law enforcement here and in Mexico feel better.

Night Vision Devices being used are indeed a Bad trend but I can Legally buy such devices now, both in this country and around the globe. title: Military Weaponry from U.S. Government Inventory for Sale in El Paso’s Black Market

content: quote: Originally posted by Motive25: quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: In reading the entire article it Mentioned 1 M16 & 1 M60 Light Machinegun(functionability unknown) as attempted to be sold to Colombian Rebels,not to Mexico and seized by ICE. The Pictures shows seized Civilian Arms, not US Military Issue. What about the Barrett sniper rifles the cartels have acquired? What about them? do you have information they were stolen Military Issue weapons from US Military Control? The Grenades used in Picture are Dummy Grenades used in throwing practice that anyone who ever Served in a Ground Component of their Military would recognize as such. I could as easily make a Grenade from a Soup can. Why would the cartels go through so much trouble to acquire practice grenades if they could make them out of soup cans, as you say? There have been 10 documented grenade attacks in Mexico this year. BTW, the M69 practice grenades I threw in my time were light blue. The real ones (M67) were OD green.Again, those throwing dummy grenades arent even US Military Issue. If you'll remember, the US Issue Practice Grenade (NSN 1330-00-178-8515)besides being Blue is smooth cased welded like the live Frag. Those in the pictures are crudely cast Commercial copys that can be made anywhere on the planet using sand casting techniques. The Last Cast Body Grenade in US Issue was the Classic WW2 Mk II Pineapple. F-14 Fighter parts arent going to miraculously fly themselves into a functioning Aircraft capable of Sorties. The Iranians were trying to acquire the parts to keep their F-14s flying. They went to a lot of trouble to get them, so they must have really needed them.Which has what to do with Mexico? Are the Mexican Authorites now claiming Iranian supplied Narco F-14's are Strafing them? A Part does not a Weapon Make Night Vision Devices being used are indeed a Bad trend but I can Legally buy such devices now, both in this country and around the globe. I'm sure that makes law enforcement here and in Mexico feel better. Where do you think Mexico gets theirs? The US is not the only Producer of Night Vision Devices. Companies all over the world produce such items. France Produced and sold to Iraq Night Vision (IR Passive 2nd Generation) RPG-7 Sights and shipped them to Saddam in 2002. You added no facts, just hot air. This message has been edited. Last edited by: LineDoggie, Wed 18 March 2009 10:07 PM

content: quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: quote: Originally posted by Motive25: quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: In reading the entire article it Mentioned 1 M16 & 1 M60 Light Machinegun(functionability unknown) as attempted to be sold to Colombian Rebels,not to Mexico and seized by ICE. The Pictures shows seized Civilian Arms, not US Military Issue. What about the Barrett sniper rifles the cartels have acquired? What about them? do you have information they were stolen Military Issue weapons from US Military Control? Does it matter? They have been accepted for use by the military and the military uses them, therefore they are effectively military issue. Given their devastating killing power, there is no legitimate reason for them to be available to the general public outside of very tight controls The Grenades used in Picture are Dummy Grenades used in throwing practice that anyone who ever Served in a Ground Component of their Military would recognize as such. I could as easily make a Grenade from a Soup can. Why would the cartels go through so much trouble to acquire practice grenades if they could make them out of soup cans, as you say? There have been 10 documented grenade attacks in Mexico this year. BTW, the M69 practice grenades I threw in my time were light blue. The real ones (M67) were OD green.Again, those throwing dummy grenades arent even US Military Issue. If you'll remember, the US Issue Practice Grenade (NSN 1330-00-178-8515)besides being Blue is smooth cased welded like the live Frag. Those in the pictures are crudely cast Commercial copys that can be made anywhere on the planet using sand casting techniques. The Last Cast Body Grenade in US Issue was the Classic WW2 Mk II Pineapple. So now you are changing your story- they aren't practice grenades, but crude castings of actual frag grenades. There's no such thing as a civilian grenade, so regardless of their source, they were still purchased with American money. F-14 Fighter parts arent going to miraculously fly themselves into a functioning Aircraft capable of Sorties. The Iranians were trying to acquire the parts to keep their F-14s flying. They went to a lot of trouble to get them, so they must have really needed them.Which has what to do with Mexico? Are the Mexican Authorites now claiming Iranian supplied Narco F-14's are Strafing them? A Part does not a Weapon Make Above you criticized someone for a lack of reading comprehension. I suggest you have the same problem. The section of the article that talks about the F-14 parts is called "context". The article was placing the problem of weapons smuggling to Mexico in the larger context of a general weakness in US export controls to the rest of the world. Night Vision Devices being used are indeed a Bad trend but I can Legally buy such devices now, both in this country and around the globe. I'm sure that makes law enforcement here and in Mexico feel better. Where do you think Mexico gets theirs? The US is not the only Producer of Night Vision Devices. Companies all over the world produce such items. France Produced and sold to Iraq Night Vision (IR Passive 2nd Generation) RPG-7 Sights and shipped them to Saddam in 2002. Which does not relieve us of the responsibility to control the export of our own hardware, or stop funding the cartels with with our money. You added no facts, just hot air. And you are ignoring the larger issues. If didn't know better, I'd swear you are trying to minimize the problem in Mexico and our role in it.

title: Military Weaponry from U.S. Government Inventory for Sale in El Paso’s Black Market

content: quote: Originally posted by Motive25: Does it matter? They have been accepted for use by the military and the military uses them, therefore they are effectively military issue. Given their devastating killing power, there is no legitimate reason for them to be available to the general public outside of very tight controlsYes it Matters, you cant claim they are US Military weapons when they did not come from US Military stocks, thats one. For another the Barrett M82(M107) was developed by Civilian Long Range Target shooters and used for Years by them before the US Military took any interest in them around 1990. Saying the Military uses it so Civilians have no use for it could as easily be applied to many things you use every day. The internet was designed for Military applications, should you burn your computer So now you are changing your story- they aren't practice grenades, but crude castings of actual frag grenades. There's no such thing as a civilian grenade, so regardless of their source, they were still purchased with American money. No such thing as a Civilian Grenade? AU Contraire. Do check with the BATF about "Destructive Devices". One can Legally own a Grenade, Fragmentation, Hand, M67 with the proper paperwork. But your point is moot dude. You obviously have no clue that you can walk into any surplus store and see these things for sale. China Prduces them as well, no US Money involved. But yet you wont see the ISSUE Practice Frag (NSN referenced above)for SALE because the US Government doesnt sell them. They are a reusable end item that gets turned back in to the Post TASC(Training Aids Support Center). If you ever handled one of those in the picture and one of the issue ones you'd quickly realize how wrong you are. You can Purchase Dummy Stielhangrenate M24's(Potato Masher Grenades from WW2) thats doesnt mean the Reich Produced themXXXhttp://www.alleramilitaria.com/alleramilitaria_049.htmXXX No ones going to be saying Krupp or the Federal Republic of Germany is responsible for these. Above you criticized someone for a lack of reading comprehension. I suggest you have the same problem. The section of the article that talks about the F-14 parts is called "context". The article was placing the problem of weapons smuggling to Mexico in the larger context of a general weakness in US export controls to the rest of the world. Specifically, there is no fear for Mexico over F-14 aircraft parts, nor any other country. For one if they arent De-Milled, they are likely coded out from usage. Which does not relieve us of the responsibility to control the export of our own hardware, or stop funding the cartels with with our money. And you are ignoring the larger issues. If didn't know better, I'd swear you are trying to minimize the problem in Mexico and our role in it. Our Role is Minimal, if you cant accept that fact-Tango Sierra go find Chaplain Charlies shoulder to cry on. US Customs seize inappropriate items every day Coming in & Going out of this Country. We dont Sell Venezuela Night Vision Devices, so explain where they come from? Other Countries Einstein.... The several recently found were US Issue, but note were found. If you had served in units that issued these to Individual Soldiers you would know the Sh_t Storm the loss of one causes for the entire unit. I was up at Ft. Drum, NY in 1995 on the 4th of july and all 20,000 Soldiers were locked down over a Missing Pair of AN/PVS-7A's for 7 hours till they were found at the bottom of some privates dufflebag in the motor pool. It would be a Hell of a Lot cheaper for Narcos to buy Night Vision Devices on the open International Market, than rely on stolen US Devices of dubious functionality and having no repair facilities for them.

content: quote: Originally posted by popsiq: quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: I can get MRE's on the open market, and while they suck they certainly arent a weapon. Fighter Jet parts could be anything from a fastener to coded out fan blades. Night Vision is disturbing, though IIRC the Miscreant who allegedly stole them was caught along with the chain of custody that sold them. Where's the Military Issue Weapons? Any M-4's, M16A2/A4's? Also is any provided through FARC from Venezuelan or Captured Colombian Sources? in the late 1970's Street Gangs in LA had a few M16A1's that were issued to the ARVN. FARC recently was found to be using CAVIM ammo. Don't you think that FARC stuff would be for sale on the other side of the Rio Grande? It always feels better to blame somebody else for your own snafus. Back to that old gun thing again: after they leave the factory they're on their own, eh? NOPE!... Next question... Respectfully, SUNLINER81

It always feels better to blame somebody else for your own snafus. Back to that old gun thing again: after they leave the factory they're on their own, eh?

content: quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: Our Role is Minimal, You are in total denial. The cartels aren't funding their operations with pesos, rubles, marks or yen, but with American dollars!
quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: Our Role is Minimal,
reply: You are in total denial. The cartels aren't funding their operations with pesos, rubles, marks or yen, but with American dollars!
title: Military Weaponry from U.S. Government Inventory for Sale in El Paso’s Black Market

content: quote: Originally posted by Motive25: quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: Our Role is Minimal, You are in total denial. The cartels aren't funding their operations with pesos, rubles, marks or yen, but with American dollars! You appear to be looking to blame the U.S. for what others do to themselves, why is that?... Look, I don't deny that the U.S. has a role, if some of our "citizens" didn't abuse drugs and if the government didn't make the use of marijuana illegal in 1937, with the "catch 22" marijuana tax stamp act, we wouldn't be facing a large portion of this problem today... Criminals will take advantage of anything that they can, smuggling, i.e. drugs and people one way and stolen black market arms the other... The point is, the Mexican government has been so corrupt for so long, that the citizens of Mexico, no not all of them, are trying to get ahead in a corrupt society, THAT IS THEIR PROBLEM AND NOT OURS!... Does the criminal element in Mexico AND the U.S. take advantage of this?... YES, ABSOLUTELY!... The point is, some wish to punish the innocent, i.e. American firearms owners, to get the guilty... Those that propose such lunacy, ignore the simplest of all solutions, END THE PROHIBITION IMPOSED ON THE AMERICAN PEOPLE IN 1937 DUE TO RACISM, LEGALIZE, TAX AND REGULATE MARIJUANA!... Do I like the idea?... NOT ONLY NO BUT, H3LL NO!... However, we are left with no choice, other than to loose the potential tax revenue, in the time of a depression and to deprive the criminals of one of their most lucrative sources of income... REMOVE THE PROFIT, REMOVE THE CRIMINAL!... This nation has two "gateway" drugs, that are perfectly legal, alcohol and tobacco... When I worked for NIS, yes, that's NIS, that's what it was called years ago, not NCIS, those that were busted for marijuana and other illicit drug usage, not a one of them did not either smoke cigarettes or consume alcohol, except for one young man who didn't smoke, he did drink, because he said that smoking cigarettes was bad for his health, go figure... My point to all of this is, we need to start acting smarter than the criminals, beat them at their own game, remove one of the major sources of income and crack down on another major source of income, illegal smuggling of aliens across our borders, that's all of them, north, south, east and west, land, sea and air borders... Punish the guilty, leave the innocent alone and for heavens sake, don't give up our civil rights to seek a punishment of the criminal... How many millions are spent to prosecute and house men and women, who's crime it was, to get caught, on more than one occasion, with marijuana for their own personal use... I'm not talking about those that sought to sell or distribute but, personal possession for their use or those that had a legitimate doctors prescription for the use of medical marijuana, legal on the state but not the federal level... Also, not just the ban on marijuana but a ban on the use of hemp products, an industry that once used to be a major tax and revenue producer... Even during WW-II, the federal government gave an exemption to the hemp industry, to produce lines and ropes for the U.S. military... In a time when we are hurting for jobs and tax revenue, to ban an entire industry on a 1937 racist drug ban, is asinine!... IMHO... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
